pros: Recent $20,000 increase in my salary. DFL has recently made good on a goal of paying staff “better than a livable wage”
cons: Staff who believe that employers OWE THEM something other than a paycheck. A handful of Staff literally resigning because they are required to meet productivity, clock in and out and other BASIC employee requirements.

pros: The staff whom I worked alongside were passionate about the local community and the people they served.
cons: The upper management were constantly worrying about productivity and the amount of money the staff was bringing in through services. They did not listen to barriers the staff were experiencing with client engagement. Some of the ways they were trying to increase billable time was outside the scope and expertise of the staff they were suggesting perform those duties. However, there was no training provided to those staff. The upper management played favorites with certain clients who had ties to the community and could potentially assist with bringing in more funders. Upper management would belittle the staff and offered no support to those who asked for help.

pros: Salary, PTO, benefits, advancement, hours
cons: Negative culture, low salary, long hours, productivity pressures

pros: Promises to clients to provide the best care. Excellent benefits. Team approach-guidance, supervision, coaching, mentoring. Great morale.
cons: N/A-need additional local/state/federal funding to help more people access mental health services (especially post-pandemic)

pros: Directions is an amazing agency to work for. From the incredible passion and commitment of the CEO to the staff who are dedicated and mission driven.
cons: There are no Cons. Wish they were located in other counties.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Clearwater, FL
pros: Fantastic coworkers, really great team's that worked really well together... It was a really great place to work at one time..
cons: Secretive and sneaky Senior Directors, lots of clicks and favoritism... HR very deceiving..

review_title: Best non profit I have ever worked for
pros: I have been at Directions for Living for over 3 years now and I cannot imagine ever working anywhere else! Directions for Living truly believes and practices the mission vision and values of the agency! Directions really cares about their employees and the clients that we serve. There is also a lot of growth opportunities within the agency. I love it here!
cons: None other than I wish I would have started here a long time ago!

pros: Good support from direct leadership, competitive pay for non-profit sector, Christmas week off and supported me in my growth towards licensure
cons: Heavy turn over, first year of employment PTO is low (does double after first year), communication can struggle across programs

pros: Compensation competitive Not for profit
cons: Unorganized Leadership High rate of overturn Benefits substandard No work life balance No continuity in care of clients

job_title: Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Great experience right out of scholl
cons: Payscale advances too slowly for longterm employment

job_title: CERTIFIED PEER SPECIALIST in Largo, FL
pros: Good people working as team meats
cons: Pay, pto, upper management, and over all support

pros: Working with children and families
cons: A poor work life balance

pros: Caseload full love seeing my patients compensation fair
cons: unrealistic expectations for seeing patients work life balance nonexistent toxic work environment last time adds to your caseload no raises

job_title: Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner in Clearwater, FL
pros: The clients and some of the staff.
cons: No reimbursement for experience, no response to suggestive feedback , no communication between administrators and clinical staff.

pros: Learn a lot about social services and community needs
cons: No resources to actually help people.

review_title: A horrible place to work! Please read!
job_title: Intensive Case Manager in Clearwater, FL
pros:
Being with your clients and being able to help them is the best part of this job! You also work with some great coworkers in the field who are just as passionate!
You may get a gift to write good reviews on glassdoor.com :)
cons:
Extremely low pay for the type of work you do, you will more than likely need another job due to the cost of living around the area. HR does not care about employees just protecting the CEO and reputation of company. Speaking up or mentioning problems in the workplace is looked down upon and can will result in a phone call from HR, not to fix the problem but to blame you for not doing more or bragging about the CEO trying her hardest...

You will overwork yourself helping clients for a company that does not care for them. It can be such a rewarding job but there needs to be a change in management big time. The only change that is ever made in management is moving each other to different positions with no experience for that specific job. I don't believe change will ever happen here because DFL is not open to new ideas they are only willing to work with the CULTURE they know.

review_title: I was promoted and I love it
pros: I have worked for DFL for more than 6 years. I started as a clinician and have recently moved into a supervisor position. DFL has always been a wonderful organization but it is sooooooo much bettter now that it doesn’t do child welfare. Working under ECKERD as a lead agency was making DFL an awful place to work. The stress, losing money every year being blamed for everything. Now that DFL has returned to its core services and mission - it is a wonderful place to work
cons: The con was working for a lead agency that didn’t care about staff, worked everyone to death and blamed everyone for bad outcomes. DFL is no longer a part of the dysfunction and is now the best place ever to work.

pros: There are no pros to working here.
cons: The place sucks. I would never recommend.

job_title: Homeless Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: The company is trying to build morale for its employees, good committees, and little perks.
cons: Senior Leaders are pressing on Directors and Supervisors to get an overwhelming amount of work done. No experience leading homeless services and not willing to learn from outside sources. Didn't understand the housing first model. Director micro-manage supervisor to burn-out. The supervisor could not train their staff to understand the mission. HR is a bully!!!

pros: Benefits, organization cares about staff and clients, competitive salary, longevity, morale.
cons: Staff shortages due to covid

review_title: This company is not what it used to be in it's hay day
pros: NONE!!!! No stability in this agency and the future does not look promising under the current leaders
cons:
Where to begin...
If salaried, no life work seperation. You are expected to work 24/7 even when you are on PTO or holidays. 
PTO amount is good, if you can get a chance to actually use it. 
Unless you are related to the CEO or plan to be a "yes" woman/man there is no respect from the CEO. The other chiefs are so out of their element, they have the CEO so snowed over. 
No pay increase in a very long time except for a meer 2% COL once in 5 years.
Longevity means nothing to leadership. 
Extreamly high turn over (even before COVID)
If you are in leadership, you are expected to sign a non-compete which is rediculus since Florida is a right to work state, non-compete agreements have very little legal standing here. No one wants the trade secrets the CEO thinks she has. Those same "secrets" are part of why three large state contracts were canceled.

pros: Good coworkers, clients were appreciative.
cons: Stressful, no work/life balance, too much workload and low pay.

pros: Good company good pay ok
cons: There are none at this time

pros: Good projects, interesting people, good benefits
cons: Sometimes managment is nit great

pros: The CEO is amazing! She truly cares about her staff and our clients! Throughout the entire pandemic, our CEO April Lott has been fully transparent and has continued to keep communications open for staff. She even arranged for staff who are considered essential employees to receive COVID testing and now the COVID vaccines if they wanted them! DFL staff truly believe and follow the agencies mission vision and values! The benefits are excellent including our PTO. We were even provided the full week of Christmas off to spend with our families and recharge! In addition, our CEO arranged for us to receive wellness gifts like, FITBITS, Sound Machines and Weighted blankets. I do not know of any other agency that cares more about their employees! I highly recommend this agency and plan on remaining here for a long time!
cons: We are working remotely now most of the time due to COVID. I would love to be able to continue to work remotely permanently!

pros: I've been working at Directions for 2 1/2 years. The CEO is a visionary who keeps her pulse on the community and truly cares for her staff.  During COVID, she kept everyone employed by getting ahead of the curve and switching to telehealth immediately. Her continuing updates to the agency keep all of us informed while in this Pandemic are vital to the staff and are true transparency. The company has great vacation days and a the WHOLE WEEK off at Christmas! No other comparable agency does this in the area.  The Sunshine Committee offers fun events to keep staff connected; turkey's at Thanksgiving, and recently a super awesome Wellness gift of either a weighted blanket, a fit bit or a Hatch Restore.  Each year, the agency holds its own "conference" to provide workshops and activities for its staff for growth and appreciation.  I have contacts in the community who work at other not for profit organizations and they do not get those additional caring perks that we do here at DFL.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Directions For Living cares not only about the clients in the community, but about staff equally if not more so. Their philosophy is that if staff is taken care of, clients will be taken care of. This means extra paid time off (including the entire week of Christmas!), a committee dedicated to employee morale and team building, frequent and open communication with leadership, clear directives and expectations as well as support to achieve those expectations, and the list goes on. The have been supremely focused on client and staff safety during the pandemic, providing the ability to work from home, as well as PPE and the opportunity for vaccination as healthcare staff. A committee was also formed in response to racial justice calls to ensure that the agency is doing all it can to support racial equity. Directions For Living truly cares about the team they build and setting a new bar for the industry standards.
cons: There are none that I can think of which is why I choose to remain with the agency.

job_title: Intensive Case Manager in Clearwater, FL
pros:
Trainings
holidays benefits as you get a paid week of xmas off
monthly agency meetings
team/family dynamics
There's so much more!
cons: I haven't experienced any cons working here

job_title: Senior Social Media Manager in New York, NY
pros: good job and earn money
cons: social media, facebook, twitter, linkedin

pros: I have worked for Directions for Living for almost 9 years and I plan on staying for as long as I can. Directions has an amazing team of people working for them and I am proud to be part of that. I have never worked for a company before that cares this much about their staff. We have great benefits and there is always room for growth.
cons: As Directions is a non for profit organization, there is always a lack of funding for our clients. I believe that this is the biggest barrier that we face as a team.

pros: Du was a lot of fun, I liked the job concept and working in child welfare
cons: Upper management didn’t always follow through when there were concerns

pros: Competitive salary. VERY GENEROUS paid time off/holidays. Great benefits. Excellent Team atmosphere/Employee morale. Prioritizes work/life balance. Provides outstanding client care. DFL listens to the staff and implements positive changes.
cons: Funding shortages (trying to help so many with so little). Position vacancies.

pros: DFL has a wonderful work/life balance. They are very supportive and encourage a high morale throughout the company. The work they do for the community and for the staff is second to none.
cons: Bring back the lunch tables!!

review_title: Worked here for 20+ years and love what we do and stand for
pros: Directions for Living is a great place to work. Co-workers are amazing team players. Our CEO and Leadership work hard to make sure we feel appreciated. I have never worked for an organization that interacts and shares with their employees like they do. I hope to be a member of the DFL team for many more years.
cons: None that I have experienced.

pros:
Ability to service a community that is often overlooked. 
Tokens of appreciation given big and small.
Support from supervisors (at least in my department).
cons: The constant change in providers.

pros: A place to call home, mission driven, the CEO really cares about the staff.
cons: Not enough funding to help all of the clients we would like to help.

pros: Definitely a position that gives you good experience and exposure to many different settings in social work. Good for a first time job out of school to get your feet wet in child welfare.
cons: Lots of long hours, many evening home visits, overworked and understaffed

job_title: Child Safety Case Manager in Lutz, FL
pros: Great team members, Free training and certification
cons: Not enough staffing support, Unrealistic case loads

pros: DFL cares about their staff's well-being. I was given a wellness gift to help with self care. They provide for their employees during the holidays, and have been essential with keeping employees safe during the pandemic.
cons: None to be reported, DFL has made progress with keeping their staff healthy and of higher standards. I'm happy it is now a smoke free establishment.

pros: Amazing supervisor and team work
cons: Too much red tape and impossible demands

pros: Great co-workers, good benefits, lots of paid holidays, able to work from home during COVID19.
cons: Can be stressful at times.

pros:

Lack of support from superiors

job_title: Social Worker in Saint Pete, FL
pros: A job to pay bills.
cons:
Very chaotic.
Full of chaos.
They lost a major contract with the state, due to a childs' death. So, they are grabbing anything and everything with no structure. But, it is never their fault.

pros: Several great people to work with that became long time friend. Staff have lots of experience, passion and vision.
cons: Too many cooks in the kitchen. Staff encouraged not to speak out when they have questions or concerns. Transparency is promoted but not acted on.

pros: they have nice programs and benefits for their employees
cons: I have never seen a management team including human resources. They treat their employees as slaves and the work overload is exhausting.

job_title: SOAR Benefit Specialist in Clearwater, FL
pros: CEO and management really seem to care about both client care and employees. Great hours and amazing benefits!
cons: Cannot think of any at this time

pros: Wellness Program, Insurance,  staff that cares, flexibility in schedule, positive work environment
cons: Nothing I can think of

review_title: Horrible. I was in training from August  til December 31, 2020. No cases just shadowing people.
pros: None at all. This company needs a do over when it comes to the president to the employees.
cons: Actually working. None at all. This company needs a do over when it comes to the president to the employees.

pros: Helping others and flexible schedule
cons: work life balance is hard

pros: Flexibility with you schedule and overtime possibilities

Schedule

pros: Didn’t have to sit in the office all day, very independent job.

job_title: Child Care Worker in Clearwater, FL
pros: Rude people, Cheap company, great employers
cons: Don't care about employers, they will fire you if something fall back on them

pros: We we're able to have the entire week of Christmas off.
cons: No support. Brain-dead leadership and HR department. Low wages and unmanagable caseloads.

pros: Benefit were wonderful and affordable
cons: Demand in the sense of caseload and needs

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Clearwater, FL
pros: Absolutely loved the employees at DFL, always felt like a community of friends. All are hard workers...All the time.  If you happen to get a good manager, then you can get your work done your way rather than an outdated system. All within guidelines of course.  Loved working in the mental health field...you have an opportunity to help them and guide them...That is very rewarding.
cons: Inconsistent management...Favoritism to some cliches...HR does not know what goes on in their own company..They will not take any suggestions to help run programs or systems any better...Never any raises.Warning...What you make will never change...unless you change positions in company...Rare occurrence...If so, maybe 25-50 cents. Non-Profit is very low pay...good for newbies... Clients are constantly frustrated at the incompetence...shame...I do not blame them...Told one to call HR...They did...They never heard back...Sad... I guess DFL thinks they are the only game in town...Bad.

review_title: Hard to Recommend at this time.
pros: Flexibility in schedule, Good Team Environment Depending on Program, CEO seems to want some type of changes to increase employee morale, however, does so in questionable ways. Ample opportunities to move around if unhappy in particular role.
cons: Upper Management looks out for one another and veils it as looking out as the best interest of the agency. So much turnover in staff that clients are constantly being handed off to a different provider and lots fall through the cracks and end up frustrated (3 Medical Providers left without notice, including the medical director). There are unrealistic expectations in regard to workloads and productivity standards. PTO is abysmal and benefits are just okay. With COVID communication is lacking between leadership to staff and people are being told to work positions outside of their job description under the alias that you are "safe and paid." CEO forced people to get tested for COVID through provider of their choosing or lose their jobs. Work/Life balance is next to nothing as you are constantly in need to tend to client needs. They also want people to submit more than 2 weeks notice when leaving and then let them go prior to it. CEO says she wants to promote diversity, yet the management team is not diverse at all.

review_title: Great Non Profit to work for
job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Clearwater, FL
pros: Good work culture and great co workers
cons: Lower pay due to being a non profit

review_title: A GOOD PLACE TO START A CAREER
pros: DFL is community mental health center in most populated county in Florida.  You are exposed to a wide variety of patients and it is a great place to gain knowledge and experience.  The staff work together and support each other and are like family.
cons: The benefits for employees were cut several times in order to raise revenue including cutting one paid holiday & higher co-pays and less coverage with health insurance.  The attrition rate is high-medical staff, therapists, support staff and upper management have resigned or quit.  Many "non-essential" staff were fired after years of employment.  The company switched from having yearly vacation days and sick days to "paid time off" or PTO.  This changed harmed many that had hours of sick days because they have to use their PTO before they are allowed to use sick days.  Therefore if they call in they have to use their vacation time unless they get approval from the CEO.  Community mental health centers in the area are similar in that raises are rare due to limited funding.

pros: Directions for Living is an amazing place to work.  All of the employees at Directions truly care about the clients that we serve and each other.  The CEO  works extremely hard to make sure that the employees feel valued and recognized for their hard work and dedication.  I have never worked for an organization that cares so much for their employees and does whatever it takes to make the employees feel welcomed and appreciated.   If you work for DFL, you are part of a great team!  A team that locks arms everyday to help restore hope for those in need and keep children and families safe !    I hope to be here for a long time.
cons: The only Con is that DFL is not working their magic in other counties yet.  Hopefully, we will be able to expand our services in the near future so others can benefit from the wonderful work that we do

pros: The only good thing about this place is the clientele.
cons: This is one of the worst companies out there. Once you talk around to people in the community you will find how many people this company has screwed over. Gave them 30 days notice was asked to leave 2 days in without pay. They make promises that they can't keep. They promise you 750$ if you refer someone who stays at the company. I had referred multiple people to this agency. I never saw a single penny of this money. When I attempted to follow up my requests were continually ignored. The Human Resources department as a whole is unorganized. The organization is very transphobic and homophobic. The agency is trauma informed with their clients but not with the staff. The staff is not given the proper space in order for work to be completed and does not allow the staff who do not have the space to work from home. They will not make the proper space for employees despite the high need for it. And don't ever expect a raise. The list of ways to get screwed over by this company is endless.

review_title: Great Company with a Huge Heart
pros: Directions for Living staff have tough jobs, but I truly believe that DFL is the best social services nonprofit to work for. The leadership team is amazing, our CEO is constantly working and fighting for our clients and staff, and the work that we do is so needed in our community. I feel like we get a lot of perks at this agency- monthly newsletters that celebrate staff, monthly time with the CEO, a huge staff event every year where we eat lots of food, play games, and get cool stuff, a fun and competitive Spirit Week, turkeys on Thanksgiving, and so many other fun events and incentives throughout the year. I love the Directions for Living brand and the innovation and expertise we bring to our field. I feel supported from the top down and have had the opportunity to grow a lot in my time here.
cons: The job can be stressful

job_title: Child Safety Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros:
Decent pay rate
Overtime is always available 
Great experience 
Opportunities to advance 
Rewarding to make everyday changes on the life of these kids.
Management does care.
cons:
The Largo location’s office is congested while other locations are not. Working in a cluttered environment where it’s difficult to maintain communication. It feels like a maze. 
New employees seem to be treated as expendable with little expectations of them actually sticking around. Your respect must be earned which is also bad for morale, especially in new employees who are just beginning their careers and looking for guidance. 
The turn over rate doesn’t just effect the remaining case workers with a ridiculous amount of transfers but it is telling these kids in the system that they’re just too much to deal with so that too becomes the norm. 
Dealing with the older kids can be a struggle and you have to be prepared to maintain a close working relationship with the sheriffs office.

job_title: Behavioral Health Case Manager in Clearwater, FL
pros: My team was great. I loved working with the families. Create your own daily schedule. They allowed work from home during COVID.
cons: The HR department is awful. Nothing but a bully who does the dirty work of the executive leadership. Horrible communication from leadership with decisions being changed almost daily. No ability to express concerns or to have conversations. No ability for raises. They said they would work with you on a flexible schedule for internship, but when the time comes do not give you any real options. Stay away.

pros: Every day at work is challenging, rewarding, and fulfilling. Seeing the work we do help so many people in need - from those who are homeless to those in the foster care system to those struggling with mental health issues - is the single most rewarding component of the job. Fair leadership, constant growth and expansion, and competitive benefits are also a huge reason I love working here.
cons: As with any work worth doing, there can be long days and tight deadlines. These are well-balanced with time off and morale boosting experiences, though, so I've never felt burned out while working here.

review_title: Good Resource for families difficult position,
pros: Working with families in need and seeing them progress is what it is about.  Co-workers very supportive of each other.
cons: The demands of the job are excessive and take over 40 hours but it is still expected by director and supervisors to be completed and overtime is not acceptable.  Be prepared to work late nights and weekends.

pros:
I love my coworkers. everyone works really hard, all the time! Nonstop. 
DU is fun
Willing to teach you how to do the job which is nice because jobs expect 6 years experience out of college. 
I enjoy my supervisor 
IT is pretty quick and on top of it. 
I love the company, i do..
cons:
Low pay living pay check to paycheck with a college degree. No raises unless forced by the state. High turnover. High case load. Everything is about money- how much funding they can get which makes the job harder and you’re able to do less for clients...spending all your time on things that will bring in more money, even if it doesn’t benefit the client. 
Lack of consistency in many aspects. 
You use your own car and are are reimbursed below federal standard because of nonprofit status .43 for the required insurance, wear and tear on car, oil changes, gas etc. (Can’t claim difference on taxes) 
Any mileage turned in more than 1 month old won’t be paid. They forget how much they make us do, how little time we have to do miles and then won’t reimburse what we drove (i find disrespectful and unappreciative due to the nature of the job) 
Workers get so much done in a day but it’s never enough and not appreciated (at a quality/leadership level) 
you’ll get assigned multiple cases in a row, in a short timeframe, with short timelines. It’s easy to fall behind and to be reminded often. 
Supervisors have so much on their plates they aren’t available the way they need to be (all about the funding $$) so things fall behind that way too. 
Workers work off the clock. Definitely not allowed  but it’s the only way to get what’s required of you done and you are still far behind. 
Getting clients into Clearwater office services is a headache because they are disorganized, rude and overbooked.

review_title: Some fabulous employees and much loved clients
pros: Great supervisor and therapeutic staff.
cons: The pay is low, unreliable guidance from administrator, too many additional tasks with insufficient training combined with ever-changing and inconsistent rules.  Nepotism as an administrator hired a relative for an director position.  Poor collection of revenue along with poor projections on funding lead to significant layoffs.  Communications from administration or managers to employees and disappearing client appointments made us look very bad on the Internet.

review_title: High stress and not enough pay
pros: Great place to be exposed to different types of clients as a brand new therapist to develop your clinical style
cons: CEO is not respected. Conflicting directions. Poor management. Clients know the staff are unhappy, which can interfere with the therapeutic process. High stress environment and not enough pay to make it worth it.

review_title: Child safety, family preservation, mental health therapist
pros: The services provided by the organization changes lives. More than 150 children are united with forever families, children are kept safe and adults with persistent mental illness are served with dignity and respect. The staff are amazing and co-workers work very well together
cons: Hiring psychiatrists is always difficult. As a non profit it is a challenge to provide raises year over year due to no increase in funding.

pros: great place to work. not many agencies have in office only positions for therapists so this is nice.  in office positions do have very high caseloads but if you are organized and have good time management skills it is manageable.  the office setting is very nice and very clean and child counselors can decorate their offices as they wish. benefits are good.
cons: high case loads can be stressful

pros: Serve the needs of community that would otherwise go unmet.
cons: Long work hours for low pay and terrible benefits.   No breaks. Turnover is high.  Leadership doesn't care how many hours have to be worked.  Caseloads are too high. The buildings are dirty and unsanitary. Staff is treated terrible.  One small raise in over 5 years for staff, but executives and leadership manage to get raises every year.

pros: The clients: children, adults and families are diverse and many want to better their lives. Love the clients!
cons: Nepotism, unethical practices, no appreciation of or listening to employees. Made to look pretty on the outside but the reality is oppressive.

review_title: High stress  - not just from the job
job_title: Dependency Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: The children and co-workers are amazing.
cons: You are completely unsupported. This position is already stressful, and the work environment and the demanding nature adds to it.  It is not the supervisors, they're the best that they can be for getting screamed at continuously. The Director  is a monster. It's a hostile work environment.

job_title: Dependency Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: Helping children and families. Coworkers are amazing. Fast paced. You will learn the ins and outs of a multitude of systems and fields - impossible to get bored.
cons: Extremely high stress level. Impossible caseload. Virtually no support from higher management. Complete lack of respect for frontline workers. Set-up for failure on a daily basis. Miserable pay & benefits. Excruciating hours. Insane turnover that is blamed on workers instead of addressing the real issues. Hard to think of a more thankless job.

job_title: Homeless Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: The culture is amazing, fantastic people to work with.  Also, a supportive environment in all departments.  I am new to Florida without DFL I would have gone back to Ohio.
cons: No cons yet; after my year in the field. I  thought there would be major differences, there weren't.

pros: Dedicated staff, great supervisor,  lots of fun and motivated clients.
cons: Very heavy case load, insufficient salary, not enough time in the day, unreasonable expectations.  Not enough time to provide services to clients.

pros: You have control of your schedule
cons: The pay, The way the company indirectly expects you to work off the clock after forty hours.  There is no real positive feedback given.  The people who move up in the company are the ones who seem to do the worst job with the families.  It is a social hierarchy.

review_title: Dependency Case Manager-Extremely High Stress Position
job_title: Dependency Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: Dependency Case Managers at Directions gain tremendous experience in social work, but the high stress environment is only for very particular individuals.
cons: Directions for Living pushes Dependency Case Managers to accomplish objectives that are unachievable, and any risks and/or situations of abuse that may result from this will ultimately become the responsibility of the Case Manager no matter the circumstances.

pros:
Fast paced, productive & fun. Life gets better here for our clients.
The staff work hard and are dedicated to the mission and 5 promises of the agency.
Community Mental Health can sometimes be challenging, but is extremely rewarding when ensuring excellent client care.
cons: Never enough funding to meet the needs of our clients

pros:
Great people to work with
Understanding
Make your own schedule
cons: With the work required the pay is horrible. You need a masters degree and you are paid peanuts.

review_title: Adoption Case Manager ready for review
job_title: Adoption Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: Being able to help children find their forever families and helping other families get reunited. Keeping siblings together.
cons: The employee turn over rate. The hours for On-Call and the ware and tare on personal vehicles.

job_title: Child Safety Case Manager in Largo, FL
pros: there is always something to do, its very rewarding and gratifying, a lot of room for growth in the company, the atmosphere in the office.
cons: too high of case loads, ridiculous expectations, sometimes unmanageable, high turn over.

pros: Working with children and families is very rewarding.  Directions for living has good benefits and fun events for employees.  Coworkers are kind and supervisors are helpful.
cons: Fast paced environment but time to catch up on work when client's do not show to appointments.

job_title: Family Counselor in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: The best part was the coworkers and families we served. There was also a flexible schedule, which was awesome.
cons: Lack of motivation and training. Management was all about productivity numbers and punitive measures. Employees efforts were not appreciated.

pros: Great company to work for. CEO is supportive of it's employees and finds creative ways to  support them and provide incentives
cons: Sometimes the turn over rate can be high

pros: DFL is committed to the clients and the staff.  The people who work at DFL are hardworking and amazing. Teamwork
cons: Work is demanding (but also very rewarding)

pros: Agency provides needed services to the community
cons: Low pay, no breaks are allowed. Salaried employees are expected to work a minimum of 60 hours a week. Nepotism, no raises in five years and only deceit from the CEO. Huge turnover.

pros: A wonderful opportunity to make a positive impact in the community!
